subject: Mercedes Hotel
description: The grand Mercedes Hotel was built in 1907. The hotel hosted social events and served elegant meals. It stood for fifty years before being demolished in 1957. Today a bank and parking lot occupy the site where the iconic hotel once thrived.

subject: Schools
description: The first public school in Mercedes was the Buck School, which has since been forgotten. However, several architecturally notable school buildings built from the 1920s to 1940s still stand along Ohio Street today, including the Graham School, and the former middle and high schools.

subject: Downtown
description: Many businesses on Texas Avenue in Mercedes Early Days including drug stores, clothing stores, and hardware stores. Streetlights were first installed in 1918. Horses, carriages and automobiles shared Main Street.

subject: Camp Mercedes
description: General Pershing WWI General Established and Army Camp for training soldiers in Mercedes beside the Main Canal off 10th Street. The Texas Historical Commission erected a markder at the site in 2012.

subject: Camp Llano Grande
description: Camp Llano Grande was was established in Mercedes in 1916 during President Woodrow Wilson's administration. It was one of several National Guard camps created under the National Defense Act to repel cross border raids led by Pancho Villa. Soldiers from Indiana

subject: Irrigation
description: The American Rio Grande Land and Irrigation Company built a state of the art irrigation system. It pumped water from the Rio Grande River to farms and orchards
heading: The irrigation is still in use today
column7: the Main Canal can be seen at 10th and Capisallo Streets.

subject: Industry
description: Early Mercedes industries included banking, brick Making, agriculture and beverage production. There was a active civic group that promoted Mercedes industry which later became the Chamber of Commerce.

subject: Ranch
description: The height of the Spanish colonial livestock economy in the Valley lasted from 1790 to 1900. Spanish Land Grant descendents owned the mid Rio Grande Valley lands, including the land that became Mercedes.  Area ranches included Toluca, Tampacua, Anacuitas, Relampago, Los Ebanos.

subject: Motels
description: As automobiles gained popularity motels were built in Mercedes to accommodate travelers with parking. Several boasted lush tropical gardens and shuffleboard courts, offering an enjoyable experience for guests.

subject: Events
description: Out of the ordinary events in the early days included fires, floods and frequent hurricanes. Early floods did little dammage as there were few buildings on the town.  There were also concerts, social and civic events.

subject: Homes
description: Early Mercedes hoes featured a variety of architectural styles, including Jacales, Spanish Colonial, and Mission Revival. Many of these historic homes remain in the Mercedes Historic District on Missouri Street.

subject: City Park
description: Mercedes City Park was designed like traditional Mexican plaza, covering a full city block with a central bandstand as its focal point. Located just south of the train station on Missouri Street, the park served as a community hub for many years before being sold for commercial development in 1950.

subject: Entertainment
description: Land developers built clubhouses to attract buyers, offering upscale amenities. Mercedes boasted a variety of attractions, including restaurants and movie theaters. The city became known for the annual RGV Livestock Show and Cover Girl Pageant.

subject: Infrastructure
description: Mercedes had robust infrastructure. Important infrastructure included a railroad depot, City Hall and Firestation, telephone builiding, power plant and a small airport. Many of these buildings can still be seen today.

subject: Nature
description: The Lower Rio Grande Valley, referred to in Spanish as El Valle del RÃ­o Grande, lies along the U.S.-Mexico border in a floodplain of the Rio Grande River. While the region has seen a decline in biodiversity due to habitat loss, many species of birds and wildlife can still be found.

subject: Body and Soul
description: In 1922, the Elks Club established a hospital, and the town was home to several doctors. Mercedes also boasted a variety of small churches, including Lutheran, Presbyterian, Methodist, and Baptist congregations, as well as a large Catholic church.

subject: Agriculture
description: Agriculture  Was Economic Foundation of Early Mercedes. Cotton and livestock set records along with citrus and winter vegetables. There were cotton gins and packing plants to prepare crops for market
